description: Legal questions covering real property, estates, future interests, and land use

questions.question: Does a fee simple absolute have any limitations on duration?
questions.explanation: Fee simple absolute is the most complete ownership interest with no durational limitations.

questions.question: Can adverse possession ripen into title?
questions.explanation: Adverse possession for the statutory period under proper conditions transfers title to the adverse possessor.

questions.question: Does a life estate terminate upon the death of the life tenant?
questions.explanation: A life estate ends automatically when the measuring life (usually the life tenant) dies.

questions.question: Is possession required for adverse possession?
questions.explanation: Adverse possession requires actual, open and notorious, exclusive, hostile, and continuous possession for the statutory period.

questions.question: Can a covenant run with the land?
questions.explanation: A covenant runs with the land if it touches and concerns the land, parties intend it to run, and there is privity.

questions.question: Does the Rule Against Perpetuities void certain future interests?
questions.explanation: The Rule Against Perpetuities voids interests that might not vest within 21 years after a life in being.

questions.question: Is a tenant entitled to habitable premises under the implied warranty of habitability?
questions.explanation: The implied warranty of habitability requires landlords to maintain residential premises in habitable condition.

questions.question: Can joint tenants sever the joint tenancy unilaterally?
questions.explanation: A joint tenant can sever the joint tenancy by conveying their interest, destroying unity of title.

questions.question: Does a fee simple determinable automatically terminate upon occurrence of a condition?
questions.explanation: Fee simple determinable automatically ends when the stated condition occurs, with title reverting to grantor.

questions.question: Is notice required for a race-notice recording statute to protect a bona fide purchaser?
questions.explanation: Race-notice statutes protect a subsequent purchaser who takes without notice and records first.

questions.question: Can an easement be created by prescription?
questions.explanation: Easements can be created by adverse use for the prescriptive period, similar to adverse possession.

questions.question: Does a remainder follow a life estate?
questions.explanation: A remainder is a future interest that follows the natural termination of a prior estate, typically a life estate.

questions.question: Is a tenant liable for waste?
questions.explanation: Tenants are liable for voluntary (affirmative) waste and sometimes permissive waste.

questions.question: Can a tenancy by the entirety be severed by one spouse alone?
questions.explanation: Tenancy by the entirety requires action by both spouses to sever, unlike joint tenancy.

questions.question: Does an executory interest cut short a prior estate?
questions.explanation: Executory interests divest a prior estate before its natural termination, shifting or springing to a third party.

questions.question: Is a quitclaim deed sufficient to transfer title?
questions.explanation: A quitclaim deed transfers whatever interest the grantor has, though it makes no warranties.

questions.question: Can equitable servitudes be enforced without privity?
questions.explanation: Equitable servitudes do not require privity, only that the covenant touches and concerns the land and notice.

questions.question: Does adverse possession require hostile intent?
questions.explanation: Adverse possession requires hostile possession, meaning without permission from the true owner.

questions.question: Is a landlord liable for injuries from latent defects?
questions.explanation: Landlords are liable for injuries from latent defects they knew or should have known about but failed to disclose.

questions.question: Can a future interest become possessory?
questions.explanation: Future interests become possessory when the preceding estate terminates or is divested.

questions.question: Does a vested remainder become possessory immediately upon grant?
questions.explanation: A vested remainder is certain to become possessory but only after the prior estate ends.

questions.question: Is constructive eviction a defense to rent payment?
questions.explanation: Constructive eviction (substantial interference making premises uninhabitable) excuses rent if tenant vacates.

questions.question: Can an easement appurtenant be separated from the dominant estate?
questions.explanation: An easement appurtenant benefits land and runs with the dominant estate, inseparable from it.

questions.question: Does the doctrine of merger extinguish future interests?
questions.explanation: When a life estate and the next vested interest merge in one owner, intervening contingent interests are destroyed.

questions.question: Is a tenant at sufferance liable for rent?
questions.explanation: A tenant at sufferance (one who holds over after lease expires) is liable for reasonable rental value.

questions.question: Can marketable title be conveyed if there is a defect in the chain of title?
questions.explanation: Marketable title is free from reasonable doubt about defects; chain of title defects make title unmarketable.

questions.question: Does a contingent remainder require a condition precedent?
questions.explanation: A contingent remainder either has an unascertained grantee or is subject to a condition precedent.

questions.question: Is tacking permitted for adverse possession?
questions.explanation: Successive adverse possessors in privity can tack their periods together to meet the statutory requirement.

questions.question: Can a landlord be liable for criminal acts of third parties?
questions.explanation: Landlords can be liable for foreseeable criminal acts if they fail to provide reasonable security measures.

questions.question: Does delivery require physical transfer of the deed?
questions.explanation: Delivery requires intent to transfer title, which can be shown without physical transfer of the deed.

questions.question: Is a covenant not to compete enforceable as a restrictive covenant?
questions.explanation: Non-compete covenants can be enforceable restrictive covenants if they touch and concern the land.

questions.question: Can a possibility of reverter last indefinitely?
questions.explanation: Possibility of reverter (following fee simple determinable) is not subject to the Rule Against Perpetuities.

questions.question: Does a tenant have a duty to pay rent even if the premises are destroyed?
questions.explanation: Modern law excuses rent when premises are destroyed without tenant's fault, ending the lease.

questions.question: Is acceptance required for delivery of a deed to be effective?
questions.explanation: Both delivery by grantor and acceptance by grantee are required to transfer title by deed.

questions.question: Can zoning ordinances be unconstitutional takings?
questions.explanation: Zoning that goes too far in restricting use can be a regulatory taking requiring just compensation.

questions.question: Does a joint tenancy require four unities?
questions.explanation: Joint tenancy requires unity of time, title, interest, and possession (four unities).

questions.question: Can an easement be terminated by abandonment?
questions.explanation: Easements can be terminated by abandonment, which requires intent plus conduct showing intent to abandon.

questions.question: Is a right of entry exempt from the Rule Against Perpetuities?
questions.explanation: Right of entry (following fee simple subject to condition subsequent) is not subject to the Rule Against Perpetuities.

questions.question: Can a tenant assign the lease without landlord consent?
questions.explanation: Tenants can assign leases unless the lease prohibits assignment or requires landlord consent.

questions.question: Does a warranty deed include covenants of title?
questions.explanation: A warranty deed includes covenants of seisin, right to convey, against encumbrances, quiet enjoyment, and warranty.

questions.question: Is notice required to terminate a periodic tenancy?
questions.explanation: Periodic tenancies continue indefinitely until terminated by proper notice from either party.

questions.question: Can an easement by necessity be created when land is landlocked?
questions.explanation: An easement by necessity arises when land becomes landlocked due to severance from a common owner.

questions.question: Does a sublease create privity of estate between landlord and sublessee?
questions.explanation: Subleases do not create privity of estate with the landlord; the original tenant remains liable.

questions.question: Is color of title required for adverse possession?
questions.explanation: Color of title is not required but can shorten the statutory period or expand the area claimed.

questions.question: Can partition be compelled by one tenant in common?
questions.explanation: Any tenant in common has the right to compel partition, either in kind or by sale.

questions.question: Does an implied easement arise from prior existing use?
questions.explanation: An implied easement can arise from prior use if the use was apparent, continuous, and reasonably necessary.

questions.question: Is equitable conversion applicable when a land sale contract is signed?
questions.explanation: Equitable conversion treats the buyer as owner in equity and seller as holding legal title in trust after contract signing.

questions.question: Can a defeasible fee be subject to the Rule Against Perpetuities?
questions.explanation: Executory interests following defeasible fees are subject to the Rule Against Perpetuities.

questions.question: Does a tenancy at will require notice to terminate?
questions.explanation: Most jurisdictions require reasonable notice to terminate a tenancy at will, though historically no notice was required.

questions.question: Can recording acts defeat earlier unrecorded interests?
questions.explanation: Recording acts protect subsequent purchasers from earlier unrecorded interests if statutory requirements are met.
